thread.title: Northwestern girls soccer team creates its own identity this season
thread.title_full: Northwestern girls soccer team creates its own identity this season

title: Northwestern girls soccer team creates its own identity this season
text:
Complete Box Score Â» 
With a trio of Division I talent, the Northwestern girls soccer team had its most successful season in program history in 2014. 
Last season's Tigers advanced all the way to the PIAA semifinals after winning their second straight Colonial League and District 11 title. 
So, much of the focus, even after this season started, was on the past and not on the current group of Tigers. 
On Tuesday night, this season's Tigers made sure the attention was now on them as they shocked top-seeded Saucon Valley 1-0 in the Colonial League semifinals. 
"In the beginning of the season, a lot of people talked to me not about the team that I currently have but about the team I had last year and the year before," Northwestern coach Kelly Bleam said. "And I am absolutely thrilled and proud of this group of girls for overcoming that and becoming their own team and having their own identity. Taylor Slack , who is one of our seniors, said in the kickoff event that we have every year, the expectations this year are the same as they've always been. They are to go as far as we can and get to every single postseason game that we possibly can get to. And that's the kind of heart that has brought our team back to this place again." 
The fourth-seeded Tigers will go for another Colonial League title on Thursday night at Northern Lehigh High School when they take on Southern Lehigh. 
Senior defender Haley Hebelka gave Northwestern a 1-0 lead over Saucon Valley when she scored off a corner kick with 1:25 left in the first half. 
It was enough for Hebelka, her fellow defenders and sophomore goalkeeper McKenna Amey , who made three saves to secure the shutout and punch another ticket for the Tigers in the Colonial League championship game. 
"We just played our hearts out," Amey said. "We really believed that we could win and we came out there and we won."
